title: Baby It's Cold Outside lyrics updated by John Legend and Kelly Clarkson
text:
John and Kelly have given the Christmas classic a 2019 update (Picture: Getty)

Baby It’s Cold Outside has fallen out of favour over the past few years thanks to its lyrics that, upon closer inspection, are rather… well, date-rapey.

The Christmas classic features the woman of the song repeatedly telling her date ‘I really can’t stay’, while the man pressures her to spend the night – with the line ‘Say what’s in this drink?’ coming off particularly badly.

But John Legend and Kelly Clarkson are here to reinvent the 1944 song for the #MeToo era.

Legend, 40, has revealed that he and Insecure writer Natasha Rothwell have rewritten Baby It’s Cold Outside with less problematic lyrics, and will perform the song with Kelly Clarkson.

According to Vanity Fair, the new lyrics hear Clarkson sing ‘What will my friends think?’, with Legend replying: ‘I think they should rejoice.’

Kelly, 37, then sings: ‘… if I have one more drink?’, with John singing: ‘It’s your body, and your choice.’

The magazine notes: ‘The song’s every bit as fun and swinging as the original, and its newfound sensitivity feels genuine, not performative.’

Baby It’s Cold Outside was written in 1944 by Frank Loesser and went on to achieve recognition in 1949 when it featured in the film Neptune’s Daughter – winning the Oscar for Best Original Song.

John has updated the lyrics (Picture: Matt Winkelmeyer/Getty Images for Vanity Fair)

The festive classic has since been sung by Dean Martin, Ray Charles and Betty Carter, Bette Midler and James Caan, Tom Jones and Cerys Matthews, Rod Stewart and Dolly Partin, and Idina Menzel and Michael Buble, amongst others.

However, in recent years, the lyrics have been re-assessed as harassment, and last year, WDOK Christmas 102.1 in Cleveland, Ohio, removed the song from its 24/7 Christmas playlist.

Seth Meyers also gave the song a 21st century reboot, ending the song after the first line ‘I really can’t stay’ with the man saying: ‘I fully respect that.’

But not everyone is on board with updating the song or banning it from the Christmas airwaves.

Arguing with a woman on Good Morning Britain who agreed the song should be phased out, Piers Morgan previously said: ‘This is flirtation. Harmless flirtation from a beautiful harmless scene in a movie. It’s a wonderful song that everyone’s enjoyed and we should continue to enjoy.

‘Radical feminists like you want to suck the joy out of everything and make this look like sexual assault. She gave consent, she stayed. Do you not read the lyrics? She’s flirting with him.’
